content.raw:
Several points with gz model:

gz model spawn let me create several models with the same name. Both are visualized but only one of them is shown in the left panel under Models. I was able to generate an inconsistency by spawning boxes with same name and removing them by selecting + del button. They were removed but the panel still show the model name.

The command does not provide any kind of feedback. Probably, by design, there is not return after sending the action.  The major problem is that under error circumstances, like asking for action on an non existing model it is returning nothing also. An use case would be to have a typo in a model name and the user don't know what's happening.
content.html:
Several points with gz model:

gz model spawn let me create several models with the same name. Both are visualized but only one of them is shown in the left panel under Models. I was able to generate an inconsistency by spawning boxes with same name and removing them by selecting + del button. They were removed but the panel still show the model name.

The command does not provide any kind of feedback. Probably, by design, there is not return after sending the action. The major problem is that under error circumstances, like asking for action on an non existing model it is returning nothing also. An use case would be to have a typo in a model name and the user don't know what's happening.

content.raw:
Is Jenkins happy yet? I need to double check.

Also, I just had a stray `gzserver` process on my machine, and I've seen [two Jenkins jobs get zombied](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-coverage-quantal-amd64/) by stray `gzserver` processes (coverage jobs testing gzmodify branch).

One of the tests like to spawn `gzserver` processes; I'd like to make sure those are being cleaned up properly.
content.html:
Is Jenkins happy yet? I need to double check.

Also, I just had a stray gzserver process on my machine, and I've seen two Jenkins jobs get zombied by stray gzserver processes (coverage jobs testing gzmodify branch).

One of the tests like to spawn gzserver processes; I'd like to make sure those are being cleaned up properly.

content.raw:
Tests are looking better; I think the gazebo_models pull request was necessary (though that means our tests are a little brittle).

More details on the gzserver zombie; I think it happens when `UNIT_gz_TEST` doesn't finish properly. Both Jenkins jobs had a problem with the test, which led to the zombie, and I `Ctrl+C`'d one on my machine to get the zombie. Is there an easy way to mitigate this issue?
~~~
213: Test timeout computed to be: 240
213: [==========] Running 10 tests from 1 test case.
213: [----------] Global test environment set-up.
213: [----------] 10 tests from gzTest
213: [ RUN      ] gzTest.Alive
213: [       OK ] gzTest.Alive (2113 ms)
213: [ RUN      ] gzTest.Joint
213: [Msg] Waiting for master.
213: [Msg] Connected to gazebo master @ http://127.0.0.1:11345
213: [Msg] Publicized address: 192.168.1.196
213: [       OK ] gzTest.Joint (6135 ms)
213: [ RUN      ] gzTest.Model
213: [Msg] Waiting for master.
213: [Msg] Connected to gazebo master @ http://127.0.0.1:11345
213: [Msg] Publicized address: 192.168.1.196
213: UNIT_gz_TEST: /usr/include/boost/smart_ptr/shared_ptr.hpp:424: T* boost::shared_ptr<T>::operator->() const [with T = gazebo::transport::Node]: Assertion `px != 0' failed.
213: 
213/214 Test #213: UNIT_gz_TEST ...................................***Timeout 240.00 sec
~~~
content.html:
Tests are looking better; I think the gazebo_models pull request was necessary (though that means our tests are a little brittle).

More details on the gzserver zombie; I think it happens when UNIT_gz_TEST doesn't finish properly. Both Jenkins jobs had a problem with the test, which led to the zombie, and I Ctrl+C'd one on my machine to get the zombie. Is there an easy way to mitigate this issue?

content.raw: I don't think the test in question are brittle, they are just doing their job: reporting when something is broken. In this case, the `gz sdf` tool was outputting a warning about incorrect SDF version. This would be bad if someone had a script that relied on clean output from `gz sdf`, which is what the test was checking for.
content.html: I don't think the test in question are brittle, they are just doing their job: reporting when something is broken. In this case, the gz sdf tool was outputting a warning about incorrect SDF version. This would be bad if someone had a script that relied on clean output from gz sdf, which is what the test was checking for.

content.raw:
Currently, several of the `gz sdf` tests fail without sdf 1.5 (see latest 
[Jenkins results](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-quantal-amd64-gpu-nvidia/387/testReport/%28root%29/gzTest/SDF/)).
Are we going to require sdf 1.5 for gazebo 3.0?

The tests were passing only with 1.4 before bc19919dcf0e, now they only pass with sdf 1.5.
content.html:
Currently, several of the gz sdf tests fail without sdf 1.5 (see latest Jenkins results). Are we going to require sdf 1.5 for gazebo 3.0?

The tests were passing only with 1.4 before bc19919dcf0e, now they only pass with sdf 1.5.

content.raw: Yes, 1.5 will be required with gazebo 3.0
content.html: Yes, 1.5 will be required with gazebo 3.0

content.raw: NAN values were occasionally returned which would cause the tests to fail. It's unclear whether NAN is a point too far, or a point too close. This line just makes sure NAN values are not returned. I suggest we handle rep 117 in a separate pull request.
content.html: NAN values were occasionally returned which would cause the tests to fail. It's unclear whether NAN is a point too far, or a point too close. This line just makes sure NAN values are not returned. I suggest we handle rep 117 in a separate pull request.

content.raw: **08:46 Mar 17, 2014**: [Jenkins Build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-quantal-amd64-gpu-nvidia/387) failures could be caused by the the simple arm model still being downloaded from the model database. I was able to reproduce the failures by deleting the simple arm model.  The other tests don't seem to require the model to be present to pass the tests.
content.html: 08:46 Mar 17, 2014: Jenkins Build failures could be caused by the the simple arm model still being downloaded from the model database. I was able to reproduce the failures by deleting the simple arm model. The other tests don't seem to require the model to be present to pass the tests.

content.raw: I think the problem is that the same cmake variables are used to specify the version number of the sdformat library version and the sdf xml files.
content.html: I think the problem is that the same cmake variables are used to specify the version number of the sdformat library version and the sdf xml files.

content.raw: Right, I've started the [issue in sdformat](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/issue/51/sdf_version-need-to-distinguish-between). I'm preparing the PR. Feedback in the issue will be very appreciated.
content.html: Right, I've started the issue in sdformat. I'm preparing the PR. Feedback in the issue will be very appreciated.
